required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Biopharmaceutics Study to Assess the Pharmacokinetics of Single Oral and IV Doses of Olorofim
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase I, Open-label, Randomised Biopharmaceutics Study in Healthy Subjects to Evaluate the Pharmacokinetics, Safety and Tolerability of Single Doses of IV and Oral Formulations of Olorofim

brief_summary.textblock: This is a Phase I, single-centre, randomised, open-label, crossover study in 24 healthy subjects. Twelve subjects will each receive olorofim as a single IV infusion, single oral dose (fasted) and single oral dose (fed) and 12 subjects will each receive olorofim orally as intact tablets and via NG tube

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: 3 Treatment Periods for Cohorts A and B 2 Treatment Periods for Cohort C

primary_outcome.measure: area under the concentration time curve to time of last quantifiable concentration (AUC0-tlast) for olorofim

secondary_outcome.measure: area under the concentration time curve to infinity (AUC0-∞) for olorofim
Number of subjects with treatment-related adverse events

arm_group.description: 30 mg tablets given after an overnight fast (Groups A/B)
30 mg tablets given after a high fat breakfast (Groups A/B)
30 mg tablets in water via NG tube (Group C)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- males or females of any ethnic origin between 18 and 55 years of age
- subjects weighing between 50 and 100 kg, with a body mass index (BMI) between 18 and 30 kg/m2.
- subjects in good health, as determined by a medical history, physical examination, 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) and clinical laboratory evaluations
Exclusion Criteria:
- Male subjects (or their partners) who are not willing to use appropriate contraception during the study and for 3 months after end of dosing.
- Female subjects who are pregnant or lactating.
- Subjects who have received any prescribed systemic or topical medication within 14 days of first dose administration
- Subjects who have used any non-prescribed systemic or topical medication within 7 days of first dose administration
- Subjects who have received any medications, including St John's Wort, known to chronically alter drug absorption or elimination processes within 30 days of first dose administration
- Subjects with or history of clinically significant neurological, gastrointestinal, renal, hepatic, cardiovascular, psychiatry, respiratory, metabolic, endocrine, ocular haematological or other major disorders as determined by the investigator
